36 Vita sancti Brendani, Abbatis de Hybernia.
SEint brendan, þe holi man : was here of ovre londe.
Monek he was of harde liue : as ich me under-stonde,
Of fastingue and oþur penaunce i-nov : and Abbot he was þere
Of a þousend Monekes : þat alle under him were.
hit bi-feol in a day : as ore louerdes wille was,
Þat beryn,*. [al. barint] an oþur Abbot : to him cam bi cas.
Seint brendan him bi-sou&yogh;te anon : him don onder-stonde
Ant tellen him &yogh;wat he hadde i-sei&yogh;e : a-boute in oþur londe.
Þis guode man, þo he i-heorde þis : sichingues he made i-nowe
Ant in grete þou&yogh;te bi-gan for-to weope : and fel a-doun i-suowe.
bi-twene his armes seint brendan : þis holie man op nam
& custe him faste, & cride on him : al for-to is wit him cam;
"Fader," he seide, "par charite : oþur red þov most take;
hidere þou come for ovre solas : and nou&yogh;t suych deol to make.
tel us &yogh;wat þou hast i-sei&yogh;e : a-boute as þou hast i-wend
In þe .se. of Occean : as ore louerd þe hath i-send."
Nou is þe .se. [of] Occean : grettest and mest al-so:
heo goth a-boute al þe world : and alle oþere cometh þer-to.
So þat berin, þis olde man : ri&yogh;t of is heorte grounde
Al weopinde he hem tolde : &yogh;wat he hadde i-founde.
he seide, he*. [al. ic] hadde a wel guod sone : and Mernok was is name,
"A Monek he was, as we beoth : and man of grete fame;
his heorte him &yogh;af for-to wende : in-to a priue stude and stille,
Þare he mi&yogh;te beo al one : to a-serui godes wille.
So þat bi mine wille he wende : ase ich it telle ov,
to an yle fer in þe se : þat delitable was i-nov,
bi-side þe Montayne of stones : þat is couth wel wide.
Þe Monek likede þare wel : and longue gan þare a-bide,
And hadde þare under him : Monekes mani on.
Þo ich heorde tellen þat : þuder-ward ich gan gon.
So þat in auision : ore suete louerd him sende,
Þat a-&yogh;en me, are ich to him come : þre Iorneies he wende.
And in a schip we duden us sone : and Astward euere kenden
In þe .se. of Occean : as ore louerd is grace us sende.
toward þe est so fer we wenden : þat we comen ate laste
In suyþe þuyster stude : and clouden us ouer-caste;
Al ane tide of þe daye : we weren in deorkhede.
Ate laste ore suete louerd : forþere us gan lede.
So þat we i-sei&yogh;en a newe lond : þuder-ward ore schip drov;
bri&yogh;ttore it þou&yogh;te þane þe sonne : Ioye þare was i-nov,
Of treon and herbes, þikke j-nov&yogh; : bi-set in eche side,
And of suete preciouse stones : þat bri&yogh;tte schynen and wide;
Euerech herbe was ful of floures : and ech treo was ful of fruyt;
bote it were in heuene : nas neuere more duyt.
Þare-Inne with Ioye and blisse I-nov&yogh; : longue we duden i-wende;
&YOGH;eot us þou&yogh;te luytel &yogh;wyle : ne mi&yogh;te we finde non ende
So þat we comen to a watur : cler and bri&yogh;t I-nov&yogh;,
þat euere fram-ward þe est : toward þe west it drov&yogh;.
We stoden and bi-heolden a-boute : for we ne mi&yogh;ten ouer i-wende:
Þare cam to us a &yogh;ong &yogh;omman : swiþe fair and hende,
And welcomede us euerech-one : wel mildeliche and swete;
he nemnede euerech is ri&yogh;tte name : and faire gan us grete,
And seide þat we ou&yogh;ten*. [al. &yogh;e a&yogh;te] Ihesu crist : þonki suyþe wel with ri&yogh;te
'Þat schewez eov is priuete : and al-so of is mi&yogh;te.
Þis is þat lond þat he wole : &yogh;uyt are þe worldes ende
[his dernelinges an erþe &yogh;yue : &yogh; hyder he schal[heo scholle, on the margin.] wende.[This verse added by a later hand in the text and on the mar|gin.]
Þis lond is half in þusse half : ase &yogh;e i-seoz wel wide,
And bi-&yogh;eonde þe watere haluen-del : al bi þat oþur side—
Þat watur ne mowe &yogh;e passi nou&yogh;t : þat oþur del to seo.
For*. [al. om.] here &yogh;e habbez al a &yogh;er : meteles i-beo,
Þat &yogh;e ne eten ne dronken : ne slepen nou&yogh;t with ey&yogh;e,
Ne chele ne hete ne greuede ev nou&yogh;t : noþur lowe ne hei&yogh;e.
Þis*. [al. For þis] is ore louerdes priue stude : and þoru&yogh; him it is þus li&yogh;t;
Þare-fore it is [her] euere day : and neuere-more ni&yogh;t.
&yogh;if Adam a-&yogh;ein godes heste : ne hadde no-þing mis-do,
here-Inne he hadde &yogh;uyt i-beo : and is of-sprung al-so.
&YOGH;e ne mowen no leng here bi-leue : a-&yogh;en &yogh;e moten fare;[Here 2 fol. are torn out in the MS. I supply the gap from MS. Harl. 2277.]
[Þe&yogh; hit ne þenche &yogh;ou bote a while : &yogh;e habbeþ ibeo her &yogh;are.' [Harl. 2277 folio 42b]
Þat so*. [al. So þat] he brou&yogh;te ous in oure schip : & faire his leue nom;
& þo*. [MS. þe] we were hamward in þe see : we nuste whar he bi-com—
A&yogh;e-ward he wende a&yogh;en oure wille : þat of-þo&yogh;te ous sore ynou&yogh;.
A&yogh;en to þis oþer monekes : þis schip wel euene drou&yogh;.
¶ Þis monekes vrne a&yogh;en ous : þo hi ous mi&yogh;te iseo,
& sori were & wroþe ynou&yogh; : þat we hadde so longe ibeo.
we seide hem þat we hadde ibeo : in gret ioye & feste,
Bifore þe &yogh;ates of parays : in þe lond of biheste,
Þat oure suete louerd haþ bihote : hem þat he loueþ her,
Þer is euere dai & neuere ni&yogh;t : & euere li&yogh;t suyþe cler.
¶ 'Certes,' quaþ þis monekes : 'þis we mowe iseo
Bi þe suete smyl of &yogh;ou : þat &yogh;e habbeþ þer ibeo.' "—
¶ Þo seint Brendan ihurde þis : he þo&yogh;te & stod stille;
[he þo&yogh;te fondi more her-of : &yogh;if it were godes wille.][This verse, om. in H., is taken from Ashm.]
he wende aboute his monekes : & tuelue out he nom,
Þat he triste to mest of alle : whan eni neode him com.
Þuse he nom in consail : & in priueite [hem] sede:
["I þenche do a priue þing : þer-of &yogh;e mote me rede,
To seche þat lond of biheste : &yogh;if god wolde ous þuder lede.][These 2 v. om. in H.]
Siggeþ what &yogh;oure consail is : to do such a dede."
"Leoue fader," quaþ þis oþere : "oure wille we habbeþ forsake,
¶ Oure freond & al oure oþer god : & clanliche to þe itake:
& whan al oure dede is on þe : & þu wolt þat hit beo,
we schulle bliþeliche wiþ þe wende : godes grace to seo."
So þat hi faste fourti dawes : & gret penance dude also,
& bede &yogh;urne oure louerdes grace : þulke veyage to do.
hi leten hem di&yogh;te a gret schip : & aboue hit albi[MS. abbi]-caste
wiþ bole-huden stronge ynou : ynailed þerto faste,
& siþþe ipiched al abou[t]e : þat þe water [in] necome. [Harl. 2277 folio 43]
hi wende to here breþeren : & wel faire here leue nome,
And siþþe in oure louerdes name : to schipe wende anon;
here breþeren þat bihynde were : sori were echon.
& þo hi were in þe schip : after þer come go[al. om.] tuo
& bede faste þat hi moste : þane wei mid hem go.
"&YOGH;e mowe wel," quaþ seint brendan : "ac &yogh;oure on schal atta[n] ende
Repenti er he come a&yogh;e : & al quic to helle wende."
Þider*. [al. vorþ him] wende þis holi man : whoder oure louerd hem sende;
& þis tuei monekes þat come last : also wiþ hem wende.
¶ In þe grete see of occian : forþ hi rewe faste,
& triste alto oure louerdes grace : & noþing nere agaste.
Þe see drof here schip after wil : þe wynd was gret ynou&yogh;;
As þe wynd hem drof est forþ : wel euene þe schip him drou&yogh;,
Euene a&yogh;e þat þe sonne ariseþ : a-midsomeres day—
Nou nuste non of hem whar he was : ne no lond he nesay.
Euene forþri&yogh;t fourti dayes : þe wynd hem drof faste:
So þat hi se&yogh;e in þe norþside : a gret ylle[r. yle] atte laste,
Of harde roche & gret ynou : in þe see wel he&yogh;e;
Þreo dayes hi wende þer-aboute : er hi mi&yogh;te come þer-ne&yogh;e.
¶ A lute hauene hi*. [MS. he] fonde þo : alond hi wende þere;
hi wende alond as maskede*. [al. masid] men : hi nuste whar hi were.
Þer com go a wel fair hound : as hit were hem to here;
At seint Brendanes fet he ful adoun : & makede him faire chere.
¶ "Beau freres," quaþ seint brendan : "&yogh;e neþore noþing drede:
Ich wot þis is a messager : þe ri&yogh;te wei ous to lede."
Þis hound ladde þis holi man : to an halle, fair ynou&yogh;,
Gret & starc & suyþe noble : euene in he drou&yogh;.
Þis monekes fonde in þis halle : bord & cloþ isprad,
& bred & fisch þer-vppe ynou&yogh;— : þer nas non þat nas glad.
hi sete adoun & ete faste— : for hem luste wel þerto.
Beddes þer were, al &yogh;are ymaked : er here soper were ido:
After here soper to bedde hi wende : to resten hem, as þe wise.
Þo hi hadde alle islepe ynou&yogh; : sone hi gonne arise,
& wende to here schip : as hi hadde er ibeo.
In þe see wel longe hi were : er hi mi&yogh;te lond iseo.
¶ Þo hi se&yogh;e*. [r. se&yogh;e hi] as bi þoþer side : an ylle fair ynou&yogh;,
Grene & [wiþ] wel fair lese. : þiderward here schip drou&yogh;.
Þo hi come on þis faire lond : & bihulde aboute wide, [Harl. 2277 folio 43b]
Þe faireste scheep þat mi&yogh;te beo : hi se&yogh;e in eche side;
A scheep was grettere þan an oxe : whittere ne mi&yogh;te non beo.
Gret ioye hi hadde in here hurte : þat hi mi&yogh;te þis iseo.
Þer com*. [al. þo com þer] go a wel fair man : & grette hem wiþ faire chere,
& seide, "&yogh;e beoþ hider icome : þer &yogh;e neuere nere.
¶ Þis is icliped þe lond of scheep : for scheep wel faire her beoþ,
Mochele & white & grete ynou&yogh; : as &yogh;e aldai iseoþ;
Fairere hi beoþ þan &yogh;oure scheep : & grettere vnyliche,
For murie weder is her ynou&yogh; : & lese suyþe riche.
her nis neuere wynter non : for her nis non[al. ne non hei] ifounde,
Ac hi eteþ þerbes nue : as hi springeþ of þe g[ro]unde.
Ne me ne gadereþ no&yogh;t of here mulc : þat hi scholde þe worse beo;
¶ For þis þing, & meni oþer : þe bet hi mowe iþeo.
To a stede &yogh;e schulle hunne wende : þurf oure louerdes grace,
Þat is foweles parays : a wel ioyful place :
Þer &yogh;e schulle þis ester beo : & þis wit-sonedai also.
Wendeþ forþ a-godes name : þat þis veyage were ido!"
SEint Brendan & his breþeren : to schipe wende anon,
& rue forþ faste in þe see : wiþ tempest meni on.
So þat hi se&yogh;e in anoþer side : an ylle gret ynou&yogh;.
here schip þurf godes grace : þiderwardes drou&yogh;.
Þo hit cam almest þerto : vpe þe roche hit gan ride,
Þat hit ne mi&yogh;te no&yogh;t to þe yle come : ac bileuede biside.
Þis monekes wende*. [al. wode] vp to þis yle : ac seint brendan no&yogh;t.
Þis monekes gonne makie here mete : of þat hi hadde ibro&yogh;t :
hi makede fur & soden hem fisch : in a caudroun faste.
Er þis fisch were isode [I-nou&yogh;] : somdel hi were agaste :
For þo þis fur was þurf-hot : þe yle quakede anon
& wiþ gret eir hupte al vp— : þis monekes dradde echon,
[& þe wei toward hor schip : ech after oþer nom,
God leuest hem þo&yogh;te he was : þat sonest þuder com.][om. in H.]
hi bihulde hou þe yle : in þe see wende faste
& as a quic þing hupte vp & doun : & þat fur fram him caste;
he suam more þan tuei myle : while þis fur ilaste.
Þe monekes ise&yogh;e þe fur wel longe : & were sore agaste :
hi cride &yogh;urne on seint brendan : what þe wonder were.
"Beoþ stille," quaþ þis gode man : "for no&yogh;t &yogh;e nabbe[al. habbeþ] fere.
&YOGH;e weneþ þat hit beo an yle : ac &yogh;e þencheþ amis :
hit is a fisch of þis grete see : þe gretteste þat þer is.
Iastoni he is icleped : & fondeþ ni&yogh;t & dai [Harl. 2277 folio 44]
To pulte his tail in his mouþ : ac for gretnisse he nemai."—
Forþ hi rue in þe see : euene west wel faste,
Þreo dayes, er hi se&yogh;e lond : hi were somdel a-gaste.
¶ Þo se&yogh;en hi a wel fair lond : of floures þikke ynou&yogh;—
wel glade hi were þo hi se&yogh;e : þat here schip þider drou&yogh;.
In þis faire lond hi wende : lengere þan ic telle :
So þat hi fonde in a place : a suyþe noble welle.
Bi þe welle stod a treo : brod & round ynou&yogh;;
Foweles white & faire ynou&yogh; : were in euerech[al. so þicke were in ech] bou&yogh;,
Þat vneþe eni leef : hi mi&yogh;te þeron iseo—
Þer was ioye & blisse ynou&yogh; : to lokie on suche o treo.
¶ Seint Brendan for ioye wep : & sat adoun akneo
And bad oure louerd schowi him : what such a cas mi&yogh;te beo.
Þo fle&yogh; þer vp alute fowel : þo he gan to fleo,[al. & toward him gan te]
As a fiþele his wynges furde : þo he to him-ward gan teo.[al. þo he gan to fleo]
Murie[re] Instrument neuere nas : þan*. [MS. þat] his wyngen were!
he bihuld seint brendan : wiþ wel faire chere.
"Ich hote [þe,]" seide seint brendan : "if þu ert messager,
Þat þu sigge me what [þu] ert : & what &yogh;e doþ her."
Þe&yogh; hit þo&yogh;te a&yogh;e cunde : þis fowel ansuerede anon :
"We were," he seide "sum-tyme was : angles in heuene echon.
As*. [r. ac sone so] sone as we were ymaked : oure maister was so prout,
Lucefer, for his fairhede : þat he ful sone out,
& mid him also meni on : as here dede was;
¶ & we fulle also a-doun : ac for no synne hit nas,
for*. [MS. Ac for] noþing þat we assentede : to his foule vnri&yogh;t,
Bote soulement forto schewe : oure louerdes suete[al. suete louerdes] mi&yogh;t.
Ne we ne beoþ her in pyne non : ac in ioye ynou&yogh; we beoþ,
And somdel oure suete louerdes : mi&yogh;te we seoþ.
& bi þe vrþe we fleoþ : & bi þe lifte also,
As gode angles, & liþere ek : ri&yogh;t is for-to do,
Þe gode [for]-to do men god : þe liþer liþere makieþ.
¶ & sonedai, þat is dai of rest : such forme we takeþ :[MS. makeþ]
Þe forme of suche white foweles : as þu mi&yogh;t iseo,
[&] honureþ god þat ous makede : her on þis brode treo.
Tuelf-monþ hit [is] ipassed nou : þat &yogh;e gonne out wende,
& alle þis six &yogh;er &yogh;e schulle fare : er &yogh;e schulle[al. om.] bringe &yogh;oure wille to ende;
For whan &yogh;e habbeþ iwend soue &yogh;er : oure louerd wole &yogh;ou sende [Harl. 2277 folio 44b]
A si&yogh;t þat &yogh;e habbeþ longe iso&yogh;t : anon after þe soue &yogh;eres ende.
Eche &yogh;er &yogh;e schulle her mid ous : holde ester-feste,
As &yogh;e nou doþ, forte &yogh;e come : to þe lond of biheste"—
Nou was hit an ester-day : þat al þis was ido.
¶ þe fowel nom his leue of hem : & to his felawes wende þo.
Þe foweles, þo hit eue*. [al. time] was : bigonne here euesong—
Muriere song nemi&yogh;te beo : þe&yogh; god silf were among.
Þe monekes wende to bedde & slepe : þo soper was ido;
& þo hit was tyme of matyns : hi arise þerto.
¶> Þe foweles sunge ek here matyns : wel ri&yogh;t, þo hit was tyme,
& of þe sauter seide þe*. [al. om.] uers : & siþþe also[MS. alto] prime,
& vnderne siþþe, & middai : & afterwardes non,
& eche tyde songen of þe dai : as cristene men scholde don.
Þis monekes were in þe lond : ei&yogh;te wyke also,
Forto alþe feste of ester : & of witsonedai were ido.
¶ Þo com atte trinite : þis gode man to hem þer
Þat spac wiþ hem in þe lond of scheep : & ladde aboute er :
he chargede here schip suyþe wel : mid mete & drinke ynou&yogh;,
& nom his leue wel hendeliche : & a&yogh;eward drou&yogh;.
¶ Þo seint brendan was in his schip : & his breþeren also,
Þis fowel, þat spac wiþ hem er : wel sone com hem to;
he seide, "&yogh;e habbeþ her wiþ ous : þis he&yogh;e feste ibeo;
Gret trauayl &yogh;ou is to come : er &yogh;e eftsone lond iseo.
&YOGH;e schulleþ after soue monþes : iseo a wel fair yle.
Þat abbey is icliped : þat is hunne meni a myle;
&YOGH;e schulleþ beo mid holie men : þis myde-wynter þere.
&YOGH;oure ester &yogh;e schulle holde þer : as &yogh;e dude to-&yogh;ere :
Vpe þe grete fisches rugge : þer þi monekes were in-fere,
& &yogh;oure ester [be] mid ous : ri&yogh;t as &yogh;e nou were."
Seint brendan a-godes name : & his breþeren echon,
In þe grete see of occian : forþ wende anon.
Þe wynd hem harlede vp & doun : in peryls meni on.
So weri hi were of here lyue : þat hi nuste whoder gon.
Four monþes hi were*. [al. wende] in þe see : in þis grete turment,]>[Here L. goes on again.]
Þat huy ne ysei&yogh;en no-þing bote þe se : ant þe firmament.
Þo huy ysei&yogh;en*. [al. seie hi] fer fram heom : ane yle ase þei it were;
heo criden faste on Ihesu crist : þat huy mosten a-riuie þere.
&YOGH;eot after þat seint Brendan : þis yle furst y-sei&yogh;,[MS. sai&yogh;]
Fourti dawes heo wenden in þe se : er huy comen þere nei&yogh;,
Þat heom þou&yogh;te heore lif was heom loz. : þe Monekes weren a-gaste,
heo criden &yogh;eorne on Ihesu crist : and is help heo beden faste.
A luytel hauene and swyþe streit : huy founden atþe laste,
Þat vnneþes heore schip mi&yogh;te þerinne come : Aunker[MS. Annker] for-to caste
Þis Monekes wenden a-lond þo : wel longue heom þou&yogh;te er.
huy bi-heolden al-a-boute : murie heom þou&yogh;te þer.
Þo ysei&yogh;en heo twey faire wellene : þat on was suyþe cler,
And sumdel wori and þicke þat oþer was. : þe Monekes &yogh;eoden ner,
to drinken of þat faire welle. : seint Brendan it i-sei&yogh;,
And seide, "with-oute leue of oþur men : ne come &yogh;e nou&yogh;t þere nei&yogh;,
Of olde men þat here-inne beoz : al þoru&yogh; godes wille[al. for mid gode wille];
For*. [om.] heo wollez party þar-of mid us : and þare-fore beoz &yogh;eot stille."
A fair old man and swiþe hor : a-&yogh;ein heom þere cam gon;
he wel-comede heom faire i-nov&yogh; : and seint Brendan he custe a-non,
And ladde heom forth with him : bi a wel fair wei
A-boute in many a murie stude : and sethþe in-to on Abbey.
Seint Brendan bi-heold a-boute : and axede &yogh;wat it were,
And &yogh;wat-manere men weren þare-inne : and ho þare[al. om.] woneden þere.
Stille was þis olde man : and ne &yogh;af him none Answere.
Þo cam þere gon a fair couent : and ane croyz bi-fore heom bere,
With taperes in eyþur side— : Monekes it weren ech-on,
And yreuested faire and in queor-copes : a-&yogh;ein heom huy comen gon,
With procession faire i-nou&yogh;. : þe Abbod bi-hinde com,
And wel faire custe seint Brendan : and bi þe hond him nom.
he ladde him and is monekus : in-to a noble halle,
And setten*. [al. sette] heom a-doun alle on a rewe : and wuchs heore fet alle;
Of þe worie welle heore fet he wuchs : þat huy er i-sei&yogh;e.
In-to þe freytore he ladde heom þo : and sette heom wel hei&yogh;e,
I-medlede with heore*. [al. his] owene couent. : and þo heo weren alle i-sete,
Þare cam on and seruede : and brou&yogh;te heom alle mete :
And ane wel faire &yogh;wite lof : he sette bi-twene to & to,
&YOGH;wite moren, ase it of herbes were : bi-fore heom he sette al-so—
Swettore mete ne mi&yogh;te non beo : huy ne knewen it nou&yogh;t on;
Of þe clere welle þat huy er i-sei&yogh;en : þe Monekes dronke ech-on.
"beoz nouþe glade," þe Abbot seide : "and drinkez nouþe i-nov&yogh;
In charite of þulke welle : þat &yogh;e wolden er with wou&yogh;—
Betere it is drinke in charite : &yogh;wan it is ov i-brou&yogh;t,
Þane &yogh;e it þeofliche nomen : ase &yogh;e hadden i-þou&yogh;t.
Þis bred þat we eteth of : we nuten of &yogh;wan it is :
An straunge man eche daye it bringuth : In-to ovre celere, i-wis,
We nutez nou&yogh;t bote ope godes grace : wanne it is ibrou&yogh;t—
For ho-so trust to ihesu crist : him ne schal failly nou&yogh;t.
We beoz foure-ant-twenti freres : and &yogh;wane we beoz i-sete,
twelf &yogh;wite Miches*. [al. suche loues] men brynguth us : eche daye to ore mete;
Ate feste of eche hali-daye; and &yogh;wan it sonen-day is,
Foure-and-twenti loues us comieth : so þat euerech man hath his;
Þat euerech frere of þat him leuez : witiez to is soper.
I-doublet it worth nouþe for ov : ase &yogh;e i-seoth wel her :
Al*. [al. vor al] ore couent nis nou&yogh;t here : ake muche[al. muchedel] it hath vn-ete.
So þat ore louerd þoru&yogh; is grace : sent us alle mete.
Fram seint paterikes Abbeye*. [al. dai : & seint ailbi also] : þat in yrlonde is al-so,
Four-score &yogh;er we habbez i-beon here : þat no man ne cam us to;
euere-eft ore louerd þoru&yogh; is grace : I-fed us hath ech-on.
And þis weder is euere murie i-nou&yogh; : syknesse here nis non.
And &yogh;wane we schullen ore seruise don : ore louerd sent us li&yogh;t;
Ore taperes ne beoz no-þe lasse : þei huy brenne day and ny&yogh;t."
heo a-risen op and wenden to churche : þo heo hadden y&yogh;ete :
And twelf oþere freres heo i-metten : Inward to þe mete.
"hov is þis?" quath seint Brendan : "&yogh;wy neren þeose nou&yogh;t with us?"
"Leoue fader," quath þe Abbot : "nede it mot beo þus;
Þer ne mouwen bote foure-and-twenti Monekes : in ore freitore beon ido,
And &yogh;wane &yogh;e weren þare-inne with us : þeos ne mi&yogh;ten nou&yogh;t al-so.
Þe &yogh;wile we singuth euesong : heo schullen sitte and ete,
And heore euesong huy schullen syngue : &yogh;wane heo habbez i-&yogh;et[e]."
Seint brendan bi-heold þat weued : him þou&yogh;te þat hit was al,
weued and chaliz and Cruettes : þoru&yogh;-out cler cristal.
Seue taperes weren in þe queor : for þare ne weren non mo,
And foure-and-twenti segene : þat Monekes scholden to—
For þare weren foure-and-twenti Monekes : and euerech hadde his;
And þe Abbodes sege was : a-midde þe queor, i-wis.
Seint Brendan axede þe Abbode : "do sei&yogh;e me, leue broþur,
hov holde &yogh;e so silence : þat neuer on ne spekez with oþur?"
"Ore louerd it wot," þe Abbot seide : "þat[al. om.] we habbez here i-beo
Four score &yogh;er in swuche lyue : ase &yogh;e mowen here i-seo,
And þare nas neuere a-mong us alle : yspeke in none wise
Are þis tyme non oþur word : bote ore louerdes seruise;
Ne we neren neuer-eft in feblesse : ne sike of us nou&yogh;t on."
Seint brendan, þo he i-heorde þis : for Ioy&yogh;e he weop a-non.
"Leoue fader," he seide : "mote we bi-leue here?"
"Þov wost wel," þe Abbot seide : "&yogh;e ne mowen in none manere.
Ne haueth ore louerd i-schewed ov wel : &yogh;wat &yogh;e schullen do?
Come þov schalt to yrlonde i-wis : and þine twelf breþren al-so;
And fram þe to þe yle of Ankres : þe þreotteoþe schal i-wende,
Þe fourteoþe al quic to helle : and beon þare with-outen ende."
Þo cam*. [orig. com] þare-In a fuyri Arewe : at a fenestre a-non,
Ase þei heo fram heouene come : and þe taperes tende ech-on,
And flev&yogh; out a-&yogh;ein ase heo cam In : bi þulke fenestre þere.
Þe taperes barnden longue Inov : and no-þe lasse huy nere.
"Louerd crist," quath seint brendan : "Ich wondri In mi þou&yogh;t
hou&yogh; þis taperes bernez þus : and ne waniez nou&yogh;t."
"Ne hastþou," quath þe Abbod : "In þe olde lawe i-founde
hov Moyses say A þorn berne : fram þe toppe to þe grounde,
Þe More þat þe þorn barnde : þe grenore þe leues were?
Ne wenestþou nou&yogh;t þat ore louerd beo : ase mi&yogh;ti here as þere?"—
Þeos Monekes weren to-gadere : for-to Midewynter was al i-do,
For-to after twelfte-day : are huy departeden a-to.
Anon to seint hyllaries day : seint Brendan forth i-wende
With is Monekus in þe se : þoru&yogh; grace þat god heom sende.
huy floten op and doun in soruwe I-nov&yogh; : þe se heom caste hei&yogh;e;
Fram þulke tyme forto in leinte : no lond huy ne i-sei&yogh;e.
So þat a-boute palme-sonenday : heo bi-heolden a-boute faste :
heom þou&yogh;te heo i-sei&yogh;en swiþe fer : ase a cloude ate laste.
Þis Monekes hadden wonder þar-of : &yogh;wat þe cloude were.
"beoth stille," seide seint brendan : "&yogh;e habbez i-beon þere :
Þare is ore procuratour : þat muche guod us hath i-do
In [þe] foulene parays : and In þe lond of schep al-so."
So þat heore schip ate laste : to þat yle drou&yogh;—
A-schereþores-day huy comen þudere : in gret trauaile inou&yogh;.
Þis procuratour heom cam a&yogh;ein : and welcomede heom a-non,
Ant custe seint brendanes fet : and þe Monekes echon;
And sette heom sethþe to þe soper : for þe day it wolde so,
And sethþe he wuchs hore fet alle : þe maunde for-to do.
huy heolden þare heore maunde— : and þare heo gounnen bi-leue
A-gode friday al þe longue day : for-to an ester eue.
An ester eue heore procuratour : bad heom heore schip take
And heore resurrection : opon þe fisches rugge make,
And aftur heore resurrection : he bad heom euene teo
to þe foulene parays : ase heo hadden er i-beo.
Þis holie men wenden forth : and ore louerdes grace nome,
Þat*. [al. so þat] to þis grete fischse : þulke daye huy come,
Þat houede ase it were a lond. : heore caudron heo founden þere
Ase heo it bi-leften opon is rugge : in þat oþere &yogh;ere.
Louerd crist, þat swch a best : scholde houi so stille
And soffri men op-on him gon : and don al heore wille!
Þis Monekes op-on þe fisches rugge : bi-leften al þe ny&yogh;t,
And songuen matynes and euesong : and sethþe, þo it was li&yogh;t,
Op-on is rugge huy sounguen : heore massene echon;[MS. echone]
And euere*. [MS. eueuere] houede þis muche fichs : stille so eny ston.
Þo heore resurrection was : with gret honour i-do
And þis Monekus hadden i-songue : heore Massene al-so,
A-boute onderne of þe daye : to þe schipe huy heom nome,
And to þe foulene parays : þat ilke day huy come.
Þo þis foules i-sei&yogh;en heom come : huy gonne singue ech-one
A&yogh;enest heom with gret melodie : ase it were for þenone.
Þe foul þat spac with [heom] er : a-&yogh;ein hem[orig. him] sone he drou&yogh;—
þe drem of is winguene murie was— : he welcomede heom faire ynou&yogh;.
"&YOGH;e Au&yogh;ten," he seide, "ore louerd crist : þonky mid þe beste,
Þat porueiez ou þeos four studes : to habben on ouwer reste :
With ouwer guode procratour : ouwer maunde for-to do,
And sethþe ouwer resurrection : ope þe fisches rugge al-so,
And sethþe with us þis ei&yogh;te wokes : a-non to witsonen-day,
And fram Mide-winter to candele-masse : In þe yle of Abbey.[MS. Aylbey]
In þe se [of] Occean : in gret peril &yogh;e schullen i-wende
In trauail al þat oþur tyme : for-to þe seuen &yogh;eres ende :
And sethþe þat lond of bi-heste : god wole þat &yogh;e i-seon,
And fourti [dawes] sethþe þar-inne : In ioy&yogh;e &yogh;e schullen beon.
And to þe contreye þat &yogh;e beoz of : sethþe &yogh;e schullen i-wende
With-oute trauail al aisieliche : and þare ower lif ende."
Þis holi men bi-lefden þare : for-to þe trinite :
heore procratour to hem cam : and*. [al. þat] was euere in plente,
he brou&yogh;te heom mete and drinke i-nou&yogh; : ase he hadde er i-do,
And chargede heore schip þere-with : and let heom wenden so.
Þis holie men wenden forth : ase god heom wolde sende—
For godes grace was with heom : þe betere huy mi&yogh;ten wenden.—
Al-so huy wenden In a tyme : In strong tempeste j-nou&yogh;,[Pissis mala.]
A gret fisch huy sei&yogh;en and grislich : after þe schipe he drou&yogh;;
brenninde fom out of is mouth : after heom he caste,
Þat water was herre þane heore schip : bi-fore heom at eche blaste;
he cam wolchi after ase an hous : and porsiwede heom so faste;
So*. [al. so faste] he schef with is breostene : þe Monekes weren a-gaste,
And criden &yogh;eorne on seint brendan : and on ore louerd al-so.
After heore schip so swyþe he schef : þat he cam al-mest þer-to.
And þo he heom hadde al-mest ouer-take : [&] huy ne tolden nou&yogh;t of hore liue,
An oþur fisch out of þe west : þare cam swymme bliue,
he gan i-mete þis luþere fisch : and smot to him faste,
Þat he for-clef is foule bouk : in þre partyes atþe laste;
Þat ilke*. [al. & þane] wey þat he cam er : wel euene a-&yogh;ein he drou&yogh;.
Þis monekes þonkeden iesu crist : and weren [gladde][added later; al. ioyful] ynou&yogh;.—
Longue*. [al. So longe] wenden þis gode men : in þe se forth so,
Þat huy weren of-hongred sore : and heore mete was al i-do.
*. [Auis paradisi.]Þo cam þare fleo a luytel foul : and brou&yogh;te a gret bou&yogh;
Fol of grapus swyþe rede : and euene to heom he drou&yogh;.[A v. om.: þis grapes he tok s. brendan : þis gode man som|del lou&yogh;.]
Þare-bi heo liueden fourtene ni&yogh;t : and hadden mete i-nou&yogh;.
Þo þis grapes weren i-don alle : of-hongrede huy weren sore :
bi þone side huy i-sei&yogh;en an yle : and mete þar-inne more.
Þe yle was ful of faire treon : and so ful was euerech bou&yogh;
Of swuche grapes ase huy hadden er : þat on þe grounde it drou&yogh;.
Seint brendan wende op of þis schip : þe grapes he nam faste
And bar into þe schipe, to libbe þer-bi : þat fourti dawes it[al. i-laste] laste.—
Sone þare cam a gryp fleoinde : after heom in þe se
And a-saillede heom in heore schip : and fondede heom to sle.
Þis Monekes criden deolfolliche : and tolden luyte of heore lyue.
Þo isei&yogh;en huy come þat luytel foul : toward hem wel bliue
Þat heom*. [al. om.] in foulene parays : so ofte heom hadde irad.
Þo seint brendan i-sai&yogh; him*. [MS. heom] come : he nas nou&yogh;t a luytel glad.
Þis luytel [foul]*. [added later.] smot to þis gryp : and nam is dunt so hei&yogh;e
And at þe furste dunte : he smot out eyþur ey&yogh;en;
Sone he a-slou&yogh; þis luþere best : þat he fel doun in-to þe se—
Þing þat god wole habbe i-wust : ne schal it no wi&yogh;t[orig. man, al. þing] sle.—
Þis holie Men wenden in þe se : a-boute here and þere :
In on of þe four studes : þe hey&yogh;e festes huy were.
In a seint peteres day : gret feste huy maden with heore tounge
And swiþe murie of seint peter : In þe se huy sounge.
In a stude of þe se : so cler þe se huy founde,
A-boute heo i-sei&yogh;en in eche side : clerliche to þe grounde :
heom þou&yogh;te þe ground was on eche half*. [al. iheled was] : with fisch al on hepe.
Þis Monekes beden seint brendan : þat he softe speke,
So þat he ne a-wei&yogh;te nou&yogh;t þe fisches : laste huy heore schip breke.
Alle þe fisches lei&yogh;en stille : ase þei heo weren a-slepe.[This v. follows after 448 in the other MSS.]
"beo &yogh;e a-ferde?" quath seint brendan : "&yogh;warof beo &yogh;e a-drad?
Opon þe maisteres rugge of alle fisches : &yogh;e habbez i-beon wel glad
And fuyr i-maked op-on is rugge : and doth fram &yogh;ere to &yogh;ere!"
Þis holie Man þe luddere song : for þes ones[al. þen one] ase þei it were.
Þe fisches sturten op with þis song : ase þei huy a-woken a-slepe,
And comen a-boute þis monekes : alle to one hepe;
So þicke huy floten bi eche side : no water man ne i-sei&yogh;,[MS. sạei&yogh;]
And bi-setten þat schip al-a-boute : Ake no water[al. ac hi] ne cam þare nei&yogh;.
So þicke huy weren a-boute þis schip : And euere syweden it so,
Þe &yogh;wyle brendan is Masse song : for-to heo was al ido;
And þo þe Masse was al*. [MS. all] ido : ech fisch wende in is ende—
Muche &yogh;wounder man may i-seo : þat wide wole i-wende.—
Þe wynd was boþe strong and stif : and drof heore schip so faste;
Al-so feor ase heo mi&yogh;ten seue-ny&yogh;t wenden : þat clere water i-laste,
þat heo isei&yogh;en in þe se : ase clerliche ase huy mi&yogh;ten a-londe—
gret wonder hadden þis gode Men : and þonkeden godes sonde.
Þo cam sone a souþerne wynd : and northþe-ward drof heom faste;
Ri&yogh;t euene with heom he was : and ei&yogh;te dawes he laste.
Þo i-sei&yogh;en huy feor in þe north : a lond deork i-nou&yogh;,
Smoke stynkinde foule*. [al. smokie as it smythes were] : and þuder-ward heore schip drou&yogh;.
Þo i-heorden heo gret blowynge : of manie beolies þere
And gret betynge and noyse i-nou&yogh; : þondre ase þei it were.
þo was brendan sori j-nou&yogh; : and blessede him wel faste.
Þo cam þare out a luþer wy&yogh;t : ful Atelich ate laste,
Þoru-out swart and brenninde— : ope heom is ei&yogh;ene he caste
And tornede him anon a-&yogh;en— : þis Monekes weren a-gaste.
Þat luþere wi&yogh;t &yogh;af a cri : þat Men mi&yogh;ten i-heore him wide.
Þo come þare out swuche schrewes mo : þicke on eche side,
With tongen*. [orig. tongene] and with hameres : brenninde mani on;
Op-on þe watere heo ornen faste*. [al. To þe brimme h. o. of þe se] : After þat schip ech-on.
þo huy ne mi&yogh;ten þare-nei&yogh; come : huy gounnen to &yogh;eolle faste,
heore hameres al brenninde : after þis men huy casten,
Þat men ne mi&yogh;ten no-þing bote fuyr : noþer iseo ne huyre;[MS. hẹuọyre]
Þe se was brenninde al-a-brod : ase þei heo were a-fuyre.
euer-ech caste is owel op oþur : and some huy þrewen an hei&yogh;,
huy þrewen alle a-boute þat schip : ake non ne cam þare-nei&yogh;.
Ate laste heo torneden alle a&yogh;ein : þo huy ne spedden nou&yogh;t þere,
And al þat lond þou&yogh;te of heom : a-fuyre ase þei it were,
And al þe se þare a-boute : barnde and smokede faste—
Strong was þe stunch and þe smoke : and longe, i-wis, it laste.
Þo þe smoke*. [al. monekes] was sum-del feor : þat heo ne isei&yogh;en non more,
&YOGH;eot heo i-heorden heore &yogh;eollinge : þe þeoues weopen sore.
"hou þinchez ou," quath brendan : "was þis a murie pas?
We nellez non-more come þare-nei&yogh;— : þat on ende of helle it was,
And þe feondes hopeden suyþe wel : habbe i-haued a wel god cas;
Ake i-hered beo swete ihesu crist : huy casten Aumbes as!"—
Þe souþerne wind laste &yogh;uyt : and &yogh;uyt drof heom forth.
So þat huy i-sei&yogh;en ane hul : wel feor in þe north,
glowinde and brenninde smoke : gret stunch so was þere;
Þe lei&yogh;e stod op an hei&yogh; : ase þei it a wal were;
&YOGH;if þare was muche in þat oþur stude : þare was &yogh;eot wel more.
On of þe monekes þo bi-gan : to weope and &yogh;eollen sore :
For is tyme was þo i-come : he ne mi&yogh;te no leng bi-leue.
he hupte out of þat schip : and amidde þe se he gan weue
And orn faste op-on þe watere : to-ward þat ilke fuyre.
he cride &yogh;eorne and &yogh;al deolfulliche : þat gret deol it was to huyre;
"Alas," he seide, "mi wrechche lijf! : for nou i seo min ende.
In ioye ich habbe with ou i-beo : ake i-ne may nou&yogh;t a&yogh;en wende.
A-corsed beo þat me bar : and þe tyme þat ich was i-bore,
And þe fader þat me bi-&yogh;at! : for ich am nouþe for-lore."
Þe feondes comen him a-&yogh;ein : and nomen þat wrechche faste
And defouleden him stronge Inou&yogh; : and a-midde þe fuyre him caste.
Þo fond he soth þat seint brendan : seide, þo he out wende :
him failede grace, hou-so it was : his sunnes for-to a-mende.—
So faste barnde þe Montayne : þat no-þing huy ne i-sei&yogh;e,
Þe &yogh;uyt heo weren feor þare-fram : no-þing bote ley&yogh;e.
Þo tornede þe wynd in-to þe North : and drof heom south-ward faste,
In þulke side stronge Inou&yogh; : þat seuen-Ni&yogh;t fulle he laste.
So longe huy wenden euene south : þat huy i-sei&yogh;en at þen ende [Judas.]
One harde roche In þe se : and þe se þare-ouer wende;
Þare-ouer þe se caste i-lome : and ofte he was bar.
Ant þo heo comen þe roche nei&yogh; : of a gost heo weren i-war :
heo i-sei&yogh;e on-ouewarde þe roche sitte : &yogh;wane þe se with-drou&yogh;,
A wrechche gost, naked and bar : in stronge meseise j-nou&yogh;;
A-boue him was a cloth i-tild*. [al. teid] : with tweie tonguene faste,
to is chin tilde þe neoþer ende— : þe wynd it wide caste,
Þat euere &yogh;wane þat water him with-drou&yogh; : þat cloth, þat heng hei&yogh;e,
beot him,*. [al. om.] ase þe wynd him blev&yogh; : þat wrechche gost[al. om.] in þen ei&yogh;e;
Þe wawes of þe se beoten also : bi-fore and bi-hynde—
A &yogh;eomerore gost þane he was : ne mi&yogh;te no man finde.
Seint Brendan him bad a-godes name : telle &yogh;wat he were
And &yogh;wat he hadde ore louerd mis-don : and &yogh;wi he sete þere.
"Ich am," he seide, "a deolful gost : ich hote wrechche Iudas,
Þat ore louerd for panewes solde : and on eorþe with him was.
Þis nis nou&yogh;t mi ri&yogh;te stude : ake ore louerd doth me grace
to habben mi parays : here in þis place,
For no guodnesse þat ich dude : bote ore louerdes ore.
I-ne habbe nou&yogh;t so muche pine : þat ich nere wurþe more.
For in þe brennynde hulle : þat ech of eov i-sai&yogh;,
Mi ri&yogh;te is to brennen Inne : boþe ny&yogh;t and day&yogh;;
Þare ich was þis &yogh;eondere dai&yogh; : þo ower broþer þudere cam
And was into pine i-lad : and þare hadde is dom.
Þare-fore helle was so glad*. [orig. gled] : and makede so grete lei&yogh;e,
For þat he was þudere i-come : and so nei&yogh; him[al. þat &yogh;e so ver] i-sei&yogh;e—
So huy doz &yogh;wane ani soule : is formest þudere i-come.
Þoru&yogh; godes hei&yogh;e milce : þare-fram ich am i-nome :
For here ich am euer-ech sonenday : and fram saterday&yogh;es eue
For-to euen-song tyme þane sonenday : here i schal bi-leue;
Ant at Midewinter al-so : for-to twelfte-dai beo ido,
Ant fram þe bi-guynninge of estur : þat &yogh;wit-sonenday come, al-so,
Ant al-so at ore lauedi festes— : so ful of milce heo is;
Ake alle oþure tymene : In helle ich am, i-wis,
With pilatus. ant with heoroudus : and al-so with[al. Anne and] cayphas—
A-corsed beo þe tyme : þat ich i-boren was!
Ich bidde þe for þe loue of god : fonde on alle wise
For-to bi-leuen*. [al. þat ich bileue] here al þis[al. ni&yogh;t] : þat þe sonne a-rise,
And þat &yogh;e wyten me fram þe feondes : þat sone comieth aftur me."
Seint Brendan seide, "þoru&yogh; godes grace : we schullen schilde þe.
tel me nouþe &yogh;wat is þat cloth : þat so hei&yogh;e hanguth her[orig. here]."
"Þo ich was on eorþe : and godes panewes ber,
Þis cloth ich &yogh;af a musel : and min owene it nas nou&yogh;t,
For it was with ore louerdes panes : ant mine felawes i-bou&yogh;t.
Ant for ich it &yogh;af for godes loue : nouþe it is me bi-fore—
So luyte ne schal man for him do : þat schulle beo i-lore.
For it was of oþur mannes : ase ich me under-stod,
Þei it hangy bi-fore me : it doth me more harm þane guod :
In mine ei&yogh;ene it bat sore : ant doth hem harm i-nou&yogh;."—
Man mai i-seo &yogh;wuch it is : to &yogh;yuen oþur mannes þing with wou&yogh;;
As wollez manie of þis riche men : with onri&yogh;te al day take
Of pouere men here ant þer : and almesse þar-of make.
Þat heo doth for godes loue : ne schal nou&yogh;t beo for-&yogh;ite,
Ake to pine it heom turne schal : ant þat huy schullen i-wite!—
"Þe tonguene al-so," quath Iudas : "þat &yogh;e so hei&yogh;e i-seoth,
tweye preostes ich &yogh;af on eorþe : and þare-fore here heo beoth—
For man schal clanliche ech þing finde : þat he doth for is loue.
Þe ston þat ich op-on sitte : and makez me sitte a-boue,
In one wei&yogh;e ich hyne fond : þare non neode nas no ston :
In a fenni dich ich it caste : þat men mi&yogh;ten þare-ouer gon.
Fewe goddedes ich haue i-don : of &yogh;wan ich nouþe may telle;
Nis non so luyte þat man ne may fynde : in heuene oþur in helle."
Þo it was .eue. þe sonenday : þe feondes comen blaste,
For-to leden to helle þat sori gost— : huy weopen ant &yogh;ollen faste.
"Wend heonne," heo seiden, "þou gode*. [al. godes] man : þou nast nou&yogh;t here to done;
Lat us habbe ore felawe : ant to helle leden him sone :
For we ne dorren ore mayster i-seo : are we him[MS. him him] habben i-brou&yogh;t.
Þou wend fram him, for it is tyme : and ne lete us nou&yogh;t!"
"Ich ne lette ov nou&yogh;t," quath seint brendan : "to don ouwer mester,
Ake doth ore louerd iesu crist : þat is of more pouwer."
"hou darst þou," þe feon[des] seide : "bi-fore him nemme is name?
Ne bi-trayde he him and solde him al-so : to deþe with grete schame?"
Seint Brendan seide, "in his name : ich hote ov, ase ich may,
Þat &yogh;e ne derien him to-ny&yogh;t : are to-morewe þat hit beo day."
Reuliche þe feondes &yogh;ollen þo : ant hamward gonne fleo.
Iudas þonkede reufolliche : þat it was deol to seo.
A-morewe, a-non so þat it was day : þe feondes comen blaste.
Grysliche heo &yogh;ollen ant weopen : ant gonnen to chide faste.
"A-wey," huy seiden, "gode man! : a-corsed beo þe stounde
Þat þou come here us so nei&yogh; : and þat we þe here founde :
Ore Maister us haueth i-pyned : bitterliche al þis ny&yogh;t
Ant swyþe strongue, for we ne brou&yogh;ten : with us þis sorie wi&yogh;t.
Ake we wollez þeos six dawes : doubli al is wo
And so we wollez a-wreken us : for on him-sulf it schal go!"
Þat wrechche gost quakede þo : þat reuþe it was to seo oþur telle.
Þe fendes nomen þo þis gost : ant ladden in-to helle;
Ant seint Brendan hem for-bed : In ore louerdes name
Þat heo ne scholden for þat ny&yogh;t : don him þe more schame.—
Seint Brendan and is Monekus : In þe se forth wende
Þre dawes euene south : ase ore louerd hem grace[al. om.] sende.
Þe feorþe dai heo i-sei&yogh;en ane yle : albi souþe an hei&yogh;.
Seint Brendan si&yogh;te sore : þo he þat [yle] i-sei&yogh;.
"Powel þe heremite : is in þe yle þat ich i-seo,
here he haueth with-oute mete : fourti &yogh;er i-beo."
Þo heo comen to þis yle : heo wenden in ech-on.
Þis heremite, þat was so old man : a-&yogh;ein hem cam a-non.
his her tilde doun to is fet : of berde and of heued,
and helede is bodi al-a-boute— : ri&yogh;t nou&yogh;t þare nas bar bi-leued;
None oþur cloþes nadde he on : is limes weren al hore.
Brendan stod and bi-heold : and weop swiþe sore,[A v. om.: Alas, he sede, ichabbe so &yogh;are: in stude of monek ibe,]
"And nouþe In liue of Aungele : ane man ich i-seo."
"beo stille," quath þe hermite : "for god doth wel bi þe;
For he schewez þe more þane ani oþur : of is priuete.
For a Monek liuez muche : bi swunche of mannes[al. is owe] honde,
Ant þou liuest bi godes grace : ant þoru&yogh; is owene sonde.
In þe Abbeye of seint paterich : Monek ich was, i-wis
And of is churche a wardein : þare is purgatorie is.
A day þare cam a man to me : ich eschte him &yogh;wat he were.
he seide, 'ich am þin Abbot : ne haue of me no fere.'
'Non oþur man þane seint paterik : min Abbot nis,' ich sede.
'Ich it am,' quath he a-&yogh;ein : 'ne haue of me no drede.
to-morewe,' he seide, '&yogh;wane it is day : to þe se þou most i-wende :
Al-&yogh;are þou schalt finde a schip : þat god þe wole sende;
Ant do þe forth in þe se : in þine schipe wide :
hit wole þe lede to þe stude : þare þou schalt a-bide.'
Sone morewe ich oup a-ros : to don is holie bone :
And þo ich cam to þe se : þat schip ich fond wel sone.
Mid me ich bad*. [r. let] þat schip i-worþe : wel euene forth it wende.
Þe seuenþe dai to þis yle : ore louerd me hydere sende.
Þo ich was out of þat schip : þane wei a-non ich[al. a&yogh;en it] nam
Ri&yogh;t euene þoru&yogh; godes grace : so þat ich*. [al. ri&yogh;t as it] hidere cam.
Elinge ich &yogh;eode here al one : confort nad-ich non :
So þat on is hindore fet : An .Otur. þare cam gon,
Bi-twene is forþere fet he brou&yogh;te : a fuyr-Ire ant a ston,
Þare-with to smite me fuyr : and fisch he brou&yogh;te sethþe guod won.
Þis [otur] wende sone a-&yogh;ein. : ich makede me fuyr faste
Ant seth me fisch a-godes name— : þre dayes it i-laste.
So þat euere þene þridde day : þis .Otur. to me drou&yogh;
And brou&yogh;te me mete, þat ich hadde : þre dawes þar-on i-nou&yogh;.
Watur of þis harde stone : þoru&yogh; ore louerdes sonde
Þare sprong out of eche daye*. [al. ech sonedai] : to drinke and wasche min honde.
Þis welle bi-gan furst hire to schewen : þat þou mi&yogh;t i-seo,
here*. [al. þo] ich hadde[MS. habbe] þritti winter : In swuche liue i-beo;[both vv. are transp. in other MS.]
bi þis welle ich habbe I-leoued : fourti &yogh;er and on,
And fifti &yogh;er ich was old : are ich gan hidere gon;
So þat of an hondred &yogh;er : and twenti &yogh;er þare-to
Ich am nouþe bi þis time— : ore louerd is wille bi me do.
And mi deth ich a-bide here : &yogh;wane god it wole sende,
&YOGH;wanne mi louerd wole þat ich come to him : and of þis world i-wende.
Ake nim with þe of þis watur : þat þou hast neode to,
And wiend þe forth in þe se : for þi wei nis nou&yogh;t al i-do.
For þou schalt &yogh;eot in þe se : fourti dawes fare,
And þanne þou schalt þine Ester holde : ase þou hast i-don are,
And fram þanne þou schalt wiende forth : to þe londe of bi-heste
And þare þou schalt fourti dawes : bi-leuen atþe leste,
And to þin owene londe a&yogh;ein : þou schalt wiende so."
Þis guode men with deol i-nou&yogh; : þus de-parteden a-two.—
Þis holie men wenden hem forth : in tempeste[al. in þe se] wel faste,
Fourti dawes euene south : þe &yogh;wile þat leinte i-laste.
to heore guode procratour : an ester eue huy come.
With heom he made ioie i-nou&yogh; : ase he dude er i-lome.
he ladde heom to þis grete fisch. : þudere huy comen an eue;
Þe Ester ni&yogh;t for-to a-moruwe : þare huy gounne bi-leue;
Þare huy songuen heore matynes : and heore masse al-so.
Þe fisch bi-gan to meouen him : þo þe masse was al i-do,
And bar þis Monekes forth with him : And swam swiþe faste
In þe se wel stuyrneliche— : þe monekes weren a-gaste.
A wonder þing it was to seo : ho-so it hadde i-sei&yogh;e,
A so gret best a-boute wiende : ase it were a gret contreie!
Ri&yogh;t to foulene parais : þis monekes he ladde ech-on,
And sette heom up hole and sounde : and wende a-&yogh;ein a-non.
Þis monekes, þo huy þudere comen : wel glade and bliþe huy were.
For-to aftur þe trinite : huy bi-lefden þere.
For heore guode procuratour : þulke tyme brou&yogh;te heom mete and drink i-nou&yogh;,
Ase he hadde er ido— : into heore schip he it drou&yogh;,
And al-so he wende forth with heom : &yogh;wodere-so god heom sende.
Ri&yogh;t euene toward þe est : fourti dayes huy wende.
Þo þe fourti dai&yogh;es weren a-gon : hit gan to hauli faste;
A wel deork mijst þare com al-so : þat swiþe longue i-laste.
"beoth glade," seide þis procuratour : "and makiez grete feste,
For ichot wel þat &yogh;e beoth : in*. [al. nei] þe londe of bi-heste."
Þo huy comen out of þis Mijst : and mi&yogh;ten a-boute i-seo,
In*. [al. vnder] þe faireste lond huy weren : þat euere mi&yogh;te beo.
So cler and so li&yogh;t it was : þat Ioye þare was I-nou&yogh;;
Treon þare weren fulle of fruyt : wel þicke euer-ech bou&yogh;.
Þicke it was i-set with treon : þe treon wel faire were,[al. & þe treon þicke bere]
Þe Applene weren ripe inou&yogh; : ri&yogh;t ase it heruest were.
Fourti dawes in þis londe : a-boute huy gounne i-wiende,
In none half huy ne mi&yogh;ten finde : of þis lond non ende.
hit was euere-more day : heom þou&yogh;te, and neuere-more ny&yogh;t,
huy ne founden in none stude : neuere so muche li&yogh;t;
Þe eyr was euere in o stat : naþur to hot ne to cold—
&YOGH;wat [ioie] huy þere founden : ne may neuere beon i-told.
So þat huy comen to a fair watur. : huy nolden nou&yogh;t ouer i-wiende. [A v. om.: Ac ouer hi mi&yogh;te þe lond ise : vair wiþ-outen ende.]
Þo cam to heom a &yogh;onglich man : swiþe fair and hiende,
Fairore ne mi&yogh;te neuere non beo : ase god him gan þare[MS. þure] siende.
he wel-comede euerech bi is name : and custe heom ech-on,
Faire he honourede seint Brendan : and on is hond him nam a-non.
"Lo," he seide, "here þe lond : þat &yogh;e habbez i-sou&yogh;t so wide.
For ore louerd nele nou&yogh;t : þat &yogh;e here-Inne longue þus a-bide,
Ake &yogh;e schullen in þe se : is priuetez i-seo,[These vv. are corrupt.]
Chargiez ower schip with of þis fruyt : for &yogh;e ne mouwen no leng here beo."
to seint Brendan he seide And spak : þis &yogh;ounge man fair and hende : [This v. al. om.]
"Þou most to þin owene lond : a-&yogh;einward a-non i-wiende :
For þou schalt sone out of þis world : þi lijf is nei&yogh; atþende.
Þis watur þat &yogh;e here i-seoth : delez þis world a-two;
Þeos half ou þinchez fair i-nov&yogh; : and bi-&yogh;eonde half al-so.
&YOGH;e ne mouwen nou&yogh;t comen a-&yogh;end[MS. &yogh;ende] half : for it[is] nis nou&yogh;t ri&yogh;t.
Ake þis fruyt is euere i-liche ripe : and þis lond i-liche bri&yogh;t.
And &yogh;wane ore louerd eche-manere men : to him haueth i-drawe
And &yogh;wane alle-manere men knowez him : and vnder-stondez is lawe,
Þat lond he wole þanne schewe : toward þe worldes ende
heom þat beth to him i-core : are huy heonnes i-wiende."
Seint Brendan a[n]d is Monekes : of þis fruyt token faste,
And of preciouse stones al-so : and into hore schipe it caste;
And faire and wel heore leue nomen : þo al þis was i-do,
And with wop and sor and deol i-nov : departeden a-two;
And wenden hamward in þe se : ase ore louerd heom sende.
Wel sonere, ich wot, hom huy come : þane huy outward wende.
heore breþren, þo huy comen hom : Ioyfule weren i-nou&yogh;.
Seint Brendan, þe holie man : sone to deþe drou&yogh;—
For neueref[t] aftur þulke tyme : of þe world he ne rou&yogh;te,
Bote as a man of an oþur worlde : and ase he were in þou&yogh;te—
And deide sone in yrlaunde : aftur þulke stounde.
Mani fair miracle men habbez sethþe : for him þare i-founde;
And a fair Abbeie þare is a-re[r]d : ase is bodi was i-do.
God bringue us to þulke Ioye : þat is soule wende to. AmeN.[Fol. 110 b is left vacant.]
